question.title: Change order of a javafx grid based on screen size
question.body:
I'm developing a javafx application for a university project. However, I realized that I can't create truly responsive applications without being able to change the order of my elements on the scene.

In this case, when the screen is small (think of a cell phone) I would like the logo to appear at the top of the form, and not on its left. However, nothing like this exists on the net, except with archaic and not very elegant mechanisms.

I trust that there is simply no documentation, and that a mechanism to do this exists. The example I'm giving you is only to make you understand the question I'm asking myself, the applications are large and go far beyond my stupid login screen: is it possible that javafx doesn't allow in a not too articulated way to create a truly responsive design?

answers.body:
I don't know if this will help you, but I did want to throw an idea out.

I am not sure how mobile keeps up with screen size but see if you can play with the width numbers and get the behavior you want. I am proposing that you listen to the stage width property and alter your view based on a certain width.

import javafx.application.Application;
import javafx.geometry.Insets;
import javafx.geometry.Pos;
import javafx.scene.Scene;
import javafx.scene.control.Button;
import javafx.scene.control.Label;
import javafx.scene.control.PasswordField;
import javafx.scene.control.TextField;
import javafx.scene.layout.GridPane;
import javafx.scene.layout.HBox;
import javafx.scene.layout.Pane;
import javafx.scene.layout.Priority;
import javafx.scene.layout.StackPane;
import javafx.scene.layout.VBox;
import javafx.scene.text.Font;
import javafx.scene.text.FontWeight;
import javafx.scene.text.Text;
import javafx.stage.Stage;

public class App extends Application {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        launch(args);
    }

    public void start(Stage primaryStage) {
        VBox vbSmallRoot = new VBox();
        HBox hbLargeRoot = new HBox();
               
        StackPane spLoginPanel = getLoginPanel();
        HBox.setHgrow(spLoginPanel, Priority.ALWAYS);
        
        VBox.setVgrow(spLoginPanel, Priority.ALWAYS);
        
        StackPane spRoot = new StackPane();
        Scene scene = new Scene(spRoot, 800, 600, true);
        primaryStage.setScene(scene);
        primaryStage.setTitle("Login");

        primaryStage.widthProperty().addListener((obs, oldValue, newValue) -> {
            System.out.println("New Width: " + newValue);
            if(newValue.doubleValue() >= 400 && spRoot.getChildren().isEmpty())
            {
                System.out.println("Here!");
                hbLargeRoot.getChildren().clear();
                hbLargeRoot.getChildren().addAll(getLogo("LARGE"), spLoginPanel);
                
                spRoot.getChildren().clear();
                spRoot.getChildren().add(hbLargeRoot);
            }
            else if(newValue.doubleValue() < 400 && spRoot.getChildren().get(0).equals(hbLargeRoot))
            {
                System.out.println("There!");
                vbSmallRoot.getChildren().clear();
                vbSmallRoot.getChildren().addAll(getLogo("SMALL"), spLoginPanel);
                
                spRoot.getChildren().clear();
                spRoot.getChildren().add( vbSmallRoot);
            }
            else if(newValue.doubleValue() >= 400 && spRoot.getChildren().get(0).equals(vbSmallRoot))
            {
                System.out.println("Everywhere!");
                hbLargeRoot.getChildren().clear();
                hbLargeRoot.getChildren().addAll(getLogo("LARGE"), spLoginPanel);
                
                spRoot.getChildren().clear();
                spRoot.getChildren().add(0, hbLargeRoot);
            }
        });
        
        primaryStage.show();
    }

    private Pane getLogo(String screenSize) {
        Pane pane = new Pane();
        pane.setStyle("-fx-background-color: blue");
        
        switch(screenSize)
        {
            case "SMALL":
                pane.setPrefSize(100, 100);
                    break;
            case "LARGE":
                pane.setPrefSize(200, 450);
                    break;           
        }
        
        return pane;
    }
    
    private StackPane getLoginPanel()
    {
        GridPane grid = new GridPane();
        grid.setAlignment(Pos.CENTER);
        grid.setHgap(10);
        grid.setVgap(10);
        grid.setPadding(new Insets(25, 25, 25, 25));

        Text scenetitle = new Text("Welcome");
        scenetitle.setFont(Font.font("Tahoma", FontWeight.NORMAL, 20));
        grid.add(scenetitle, 0, 0, 2, 1);

        Label userName = new Label("User Name:");
        grid.add(userName, 0, 1);

        TextField userTextField = new TextField();
        grid.add(userTextField, 1, 1);

        Label pw = new Label("Password:");
        grid.add(pw, 0, 2);

        PasswordField pwBox = new PasswordField();
        grid.add(pwBox, 1, 2);

        Button btn = new Button("Sign in");
        HBox hbBtn = new HBox(10);
        hbBtn.setAlignment(Pos.BOTTOM_RIGHT);
        hbBtn.getChildren().add(btn);
        grid.add(hbBtn, 1, 4);

        final Text actiontarget = new Text();
        grid.add(actiontarget, 1, 6);
        
        grid.setStyle("-fx-background-color: yellow;");
        
        
        return new StackPane(grid);
    }
}

question_comments.body: The documentation for layout mechanism is here and for the different layout panes following the links for the relevant classes from that page. There is also an official tutorial and several good third party ones (like this). Generally it is just a case of using the layout pane you want, as mentioned in other comments. What is wrong with the suggestion to use a FlowPane?

The general answer is to "use the layouts that adjust as you want them to". See the documentation of the various layouts for information on how they work. If none of the standard layouts work for you then you can search for a third-party library that provides what you need. And if you still can't find anything that fits your needs, then you can always subclass Region or Pane to create your own layout.

The point of my question goes beyond my application case. I was hoping there was a general answer, a best practice, an objective way to have the layout changes to fit the screen. And I was hoping that there was simply no documentation to implement it. But apparently, that is not the case. Anyway, thanks

If the question was just regarding the login page and not about other app pages, and how to do this in general. And suppose the question provided an minimal reproducible example for the login screen and mockups of what it should look like at different resolutions. In that case, you likely get a specific answer that shows how to achieve what you want for that one screen, and perhaps you could apply some of the principles from that answer to the rest of your app.

This question is too difficult to answer in a general way, so unfortunately won't fit well in a StackOverflow format. It is not that it can't be done, it just may be difficult to do and explain when "the applications are large and go far beyond my stupid login screen". You may review How to create responsive desktop applications UI in JavaFx? for a limited selection of layout tips.
The GridPane layout is not designed to "wrap" its children. Perhaps TilePane and/or FlowPane provides what you need. Note you can nest layouts to get the general "shape" you want for the UI.
